Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of Wagner, may have had support from Russia's military, according to U.S. officials. They are trying to determine if General Sergei Surovikin, the former top Russian commander in Ukraine, aided Prigozhin's plans to rebel against Russia's military leadership. American officials are also looking into whether other Russian generals supported Prigozhin's attempt to change the leadership of the Defense Ministry by force.President Vladimir V. Putin must now decide if General Surovikin helped Prigozhin and how he should respond. On Tuesday, the Russian domestic intelligence agency said that it was dropping criminal charges against Prigozhin and members of his force. If Putin finds evidence that Surovikin more directly helped Prigozhin, he will likely have to remove him from his command.U.S. officials have an interest in pushing out information that undermines the standing of General Surovikin, as his removal would benefit Ukraine. American officials have avoided discussing the rebellion publicly, out of fear of feeding Putin's narrative that the unrest was orchestrated by the West.
